stork.feather

Class Tap<R extends Resource>

  • java.lang.Object
    • stork.feather.ProxyElement<R>
      • stork.feather.Tap<R>
  • Direct Known Subclasses:
    Pump

    public abstract class Tap<R extends Resource>
extends ProxyElement<R>
    A Tap emits Slices to an attached Sink. The Tap should provide methods for regulating the flow of Slices (see ProxyElement.pause() and ProxyElement.resume()) to allow attached Sinks to prevent themselves from being overwhelmed.

    Taps may either be active or passive. The distinction lies in how the Tap manages Resource ordering and initialization. Whether a Tap is active or passive influences the semantics of initialize(...).

    Active Taps handle their own initialization and ordering of Resources, which are typically imposed by some external mechanism. These Taps will call initialize(...) themselves when a Resource is ready for transfer. An example is an incoming multipart HTTP request viewed as a Tap, where initialize(...) will be called by the Tap itself for every incoming file. Active Taps may override initialize(Relative) to implement custom behavior, but must ultimately return the result of super.initialize(...) to initialize the pipeline.

    Passive Taps expect to have Resources explicitly requested by some active requestor process. In that sense, these Taps behave somewhat like a traditional data server. An example is an FTP session, where the Tap waits for initialize(...) to be called on each Resource when it is ready to be transferred. Passive Taps must override initialize(Relative) to implement behavior that starts the transfer of data for the requested Resource.

    A passive Tap can be converted into an active Tap through the use of a Pump adapter. A Pump uses a Crawler to traverse a collection Resources and transfers each in turn. Pumps will be transparently inserted into the pipeline when a passive Tap is attached to a Sink.

    See Also:
    Sink, Slice

      • attach

        public final <D extends Resource> ProxyTransfer<R,D> attach(Sink<D> sink)
        Attach this tap to a Sink. Once this method is called, ProxyElement.start() will be called and the Tap may begin emitting Slices.
        Parameters:
        sink - a Sink to attach.
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - if sink is null.
        IllegalStateException - is a Sink has already been attached.

      • initialize

        public Bell<R> initialize(Relative<R> resource)
        Initialize the pipeline to transfer a Resource. Active Taps should call this to initialize downstream elements for transfer. Active subclasses may override this, but must return super.initialize(resource). The returned Bell will ring when the attached Sink is ready to transfer data.

        Passive Taps will have this called to indicate that a transfer should begin, and must not call super.initialize(...), or an IllegalStateException will be thrown. A Bell must be returned that will be rung when the Sink is ready to receive Slices from resource. Once the returned Bell has been rung, and any asynchronous preparations in the Tap have completed, the Tap may begin draining Slices for resource.

        Specified by:
        initialize in class ProxyElement<R extends Resource>
        Parameters:
        resource - the Resource which should be initialized, in a Relative wrapper.
        Returns:
        A Bell which will ring when data for resource is ready to be drained, or null if data can begin being drained immediately.
        Throws:
        IllegalStateException - if this Tap is passive and this method has not been overridden.

      • initialize

        public final Bell<R> initialize(Path path)
        Initialize the transfer of data for the Resource specified by path relative to the root Resource. This simply delegates to initialize(Relative), and is made available as a convenience.
        Parameters:
        path - the path to the Resource which should be initialized relative to the root.
        Returns:
        A Bell which will ring when data for path is ready to be drained, or null if data can begin being drained immediately.

      • drain

        public final void drain(Relative<Slice> slice)
        Drain a Slice to the Sink. This method (or one of its analogues) should be called by Taps to drain Slices through the pipeline.
        Specified by:
        drain in class ProxyElement<R extends Resource>
        Parameters:
        slice - a Slice being drained through the pipeline.

      • drain

        public final void drain(Slice slice)

        Parameters:
        slice - a Slice being drained through the pipeline.
        Throws:
        IllegalStateException - if this method is called when the pipeline has not been initialized.

      • finalize

        public final void finalize(Relative<R> resource)
        Finalize the transfer of a Resource. This method (or one of its analogues) should be called by Taps to indicate to the attached Sink that a given Resource has finished transferring. Non-data Resources do not need to be finalized.
        Specified by:
        finalize in class ProxyElement<R extends Resource>
        Parameters:
        resource - the Resource being finalized.

      • finalize

        public final void finalize(Path path)
        Finalize the transfer of data for the Resource specified by path. This simply delegates to finalize(Relative).
        Parameters:
        path - the path to the Resource which should be finalized relative to the root.
        Throws:
        IllegalStateException - if this method is called when the pipeline has not been initialized.
